instructions.sample1_instruction:
Our adventurer wants to collect coins.  But she can only use 4 blocks to get them.

Can you help her grab as many as she can using just 4 blocks?
instructions.sample10_instruction: Now you can use loops to draw whatever you like!
instructions.sample10a_instruction:
You have helped the adventurer and her bee!  As a reward, please stay and play around in my magical village. 

You should have everything you need to create a game of your own.
instructions.sample2_instruction: Use what you've learned to help bee gather all of this honey using only the blocks that you have here.
instructions.sample2a_instruction: Use what you've learned to help bee gather all of this honey using only 4 blocks.
instructions.sample3_instruction: Now you can help bee make all of the honey using just the blocks in the toolbox.
instructions.sample3assessment_instruction: Can you figure out how to gather all of this nectar in just one try?
instructions.sample4_instruction:
Our adventurer has found a stash of coins in this cave.

Can you help her grab as many as she can using just 7 blocks?
instructions.sample5_instruction: Help bee make all of the honey.
instructions.sample6_instruction: Challenge: Help bee get all of the nectar.
instructions.sample7assessment_instruction: Can you help bee make all of the honey in just one try?
instructions.sample8_instruction: Look at this trove of coins! How many can you get the adventurer to grab?
instructions.sample9_instruction: Use loops to help the artist connect all of the dots.
instructions.sample9a_instruction: The wizard has found his potions!  Use everything you have learned to help him collect them.
instructions.scrat 16 (copy 1)_instruction: Acorn! Acorn! Acorn! Use an "if" block to get me there with the fewest number of blocks.
instructions.scrat 16_instruction: Acorn! Acorn! Acorn! Use an "if" block to get me there with the fewest number of blocks.
instructions.scrat 17 (copy 1)_instruction: Ok, let's do that again for practice - this isn't very different, but watch out for the <insert obstacle name for Scrat>!
instructions.scrat 17_instruction: Ok, let's do that again for practice - this isn't very different, but watch out for the wall!
instructions.scrat 18 (copy 1)_instruction: The "If-else" blocks checks a condition, and then does one thing OR another. To get me to the acorn try to use this new block.
instructions.scrat 18_instruction: The "If-else" blocks checks a condition, and then does one thing OR another. To get me to the acorn try to use this new block.
instructions.scrat 19 (copy 1)_instruction: One more practice of the "if-else" block, can you get it right on your first try?
instructions.scrat 19_instruction: One more practice of the "if-else" block, can you get it right on your first try?
instructions.scrat 20_instruction: Can you add just 3 blocks to help me solve a more complex maze? If you do it right, I can walk any curvy path no matter the length. Hurry! The ice is melting!
instructions.subgoal U3 L4 introducing subgoal labels: Introduce orient turtle and move turtle
instructions.subgoal U3L2 Using Simple Commands_instr: Draw a 1x1 square above and to the left of the turtle's starting position. Click to see full instructions.
instructions.subgoalU3L2_TurtleSquare_right_instructi: Draw a square to the front and to the right of the starting location. (Click to show full instructions)
instructions.testArtistForTestK_instruction: The Artist is trying to draw a line five times, but can't get it right.  Can you help?
instructions.valentine_artist_03_instruction: Now try something on your own!
instructions.weird_playLab_instruction: About My Robot Project! Write code so that clicking on each bird shows a new fact about your robot.

markdown_instructions.'pre-assessment survey q25A'_markdown_in: If yes, what computer science course(s) had you taken before your current computer science  class?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist 1 new_markdown_instruction: Hi, I'm an artist. You can write code to make me draw almost anything. Use a few blocks to make me draw over the grey lines in the picture. (Each line is 100 pixels long)
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist 11_markdown_instruction: Give the stop sign a border by making an octagon with 100 pixels sides.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist 12_markdown_instruction:
Create a circle to finish the eyeball! 

If the artist turns 1 degree with each loop, how many times do you need to repeat the code to draw a circle?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist 2 new_markdown_instruction: This house has a half-finished wall. Each side is 100, but the half-finished wall is only 50. Complete the wall.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist 3.4_markdown_instruction: The jump block moves the artist without drawing. Draw the dashed line using both the `jump forward` and `move forward` blocks. Each line is 50 pixels long.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist 3new_markdown_instruction:
The red hat is 100 pixels tall. Finish drawing a black hat that is 70 pixels shorter. 

*(Note: The width of each hat is 50 pixels.)*
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist 4_markdown_instruction: Help me complete the house for this cat.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist 6_markdown_instruction: This house needs a roof! Draw the triangle. Hint: all three sides are the same length.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist 7_markdown_instruction:
Finish drawing the last set of windows on the school so that everyone in class can see outside. 

The sides of each square window pane are 25 pixels long.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist 8_markdown_instruction:
Time to build a barn!

Make the rooms for each animal by splitting the barn into 2 equal-sized squares. 

Hint: The rectangle is 200 pixels wide and 100 pixels tall.

There are many different ways to solve this puzzle.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Assessment 1_markdown_instruc: **Assessment:** Finish drawing the last tooth. It is 25 pixels wide and 25 pixels tall.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 1_markdown_instruct: This hat should only be 50 pixels wide. Can you fix it?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 10_markdown_instruc:
The direction pad on my game controller is too narrow. 

Can you make it wider by 10 pixels?

Try running the code first to see what's wrong.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 11_markdown_instruc:
My snowflake is falling apart!

Can you figure out what's going wrong?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 2_markdown_instruct:
This code for the cat's whiskers is wrong. 

Fix this code to draw whiskers that are all the same length.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 3_markdown_instruct:
My boat has a hole! 

What do you need to fix to make the ends meet?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 5_markdown_instruct:
The code that we have for the leg and foot is wrong. 

Can you fix it?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 6_markdown_instruct:
Looks like I'm sitting on a chair thats missing a leg!

Edit the code to draw the last leg.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 7_markdown_instruct:
Looks like the C in code is drawn backwards!

Can you make it look like a C again?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 8_markdown_instruct:
My teacher says that I should finish what I start!

Help me finish my pinwheel. Can you figure out what's wrong?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 9_markdown_instruct:
Something is off!

The code for this stem is wrong. Can you figure out how to get the artist to trace the stem the right way?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging Assessment 1_markdo:
**Assessment:** 
Why does this square end up being 75 pixels too small on each side?  

Where does the code go wrong?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 1 a_markdown_instru:
"Me zombie artist. Me love drawing!" 

Help the zombie draw square glasses.  

The bridge between the glasses is 25 pixels shorter than the width of the squares, which is 100 pixels.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 1_markdown_instruct:
"Me zombie artist. Me love drawing!" 

Help the zombie draw square glasses.  

The bridge between the glasses is 25 pixels shorter than the width of the squares, which is 100 pixels.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 10_markdown_instruc:
**Freeplay:** Here are two functions, one to draw a big gear and one to draw a small gear.  

Use them to draw the inside of a machine!
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 11 a_markdown_instr:
We've renamed the `draw a square` function to `draw a hexagon`, but it's still giving us squares!  

Can you modify the `draw a hexagon` function to draw a hexagon with 50 pixel sides? 

Draw the image using the new function!
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 11.5 a_markdown_ins:
Here's that same `draw a hexagon` function. 

What happens if you loop the main program **6** times, turning **60** degrees each time you loop?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 11.5_markdown_instr:
Here's that same `draw a hexagon` function. 

What happens if you loop the main program 6 times, turning 60 degrees each time you loop?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 11_markdown_instruc:
We've renamed the `draw a square` function to `draw a hexagon`, but it's still giving us squares!  

Can you modify the `draw a hexagon` function to draw a hexagon with 50 pixel sides? 

Draw the image using the new function!
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 12 Mike_markdown_in:
Functions are really great for drawing complex things multiple times. 

Can you use the `draw a flower` function to fill the rest of the planter box?
The plants are all 100 pixels apart.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 12 a_markdown_instr:
Functions are really great for drawing complex things multiple times. 

Can you use the `draw a flower` function to fill the rest of the planter box?
The plants are all 100 pixels apart.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 12_markdown_instruc:
Functions are really great for drawing complex things multiple times. 

Can you use the `draw a flower` function to fill the rest of the planter box?
The plants are all 100 pixels apart.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 2 a_markdown_instru:
Functions let you define new blocks! 

We've moved the blocks needed for drawing a square into a function called `draw a square`. This time, use the small green `draw a square` block to call this new function and create the glasses. 

The squares in this drawing are 75 pixels apart.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 2_markdown_instruct:
Functions let you define new blocks! 

We've moved the blocks needed for drawing a square into a function called `draw a square`. This time, use the `draw a square` function to create the glasses. 

The squares are 75 pixels apart.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 3 a_markdown_instru:
Edit the "draw a square" function to draw glasses with frames that are 115px on each side. 

The squares are now 45 pixels apart.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 3_markdown_instruct:
Edit the function to draw a square with a side length of 115 to draw the bigger glasses. 

The squares are now 45 pixels apart.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 4 a_markdown_instru: Now, put the function inside of a loop and add an extra turn to draw these three squares.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 4_markdown_instruct: Now, put the function inside of a loop to draw these three squares.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 9_markdown_instruct:
**Freeplay:** Here is a snowflake function. Experiment with it to create a winter scene! 

This is a free play level, so there is no puzzle to solve. Have fun!
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 1_markdown_instruction: Can you make a hexagon with sides that are 100 pixels long to finish the cell? Remember, that means that you will only need to turn 60 degrees!
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 2_markdown_instruction: Now use a repeat block to make the cell a shell.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 1_markdown_instruct: Let's draw this robot's head! Can you make a square with sides that are 100 pixels?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 10_markdown_instruc: Now let's connect a bunch of V's together in a loop.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 11_markdown_instruc:
Time to make something snazzy! 

Rebuild the code from the last puzzle, but this time, add a left turn of 30 degrees inside the loop. Now, repeat it 24 times instead of 8.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 12_markdown_instruc: Draw a diamond with sides of 100 pixels.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 13_markdown_instruc:
We are going to start you with some code (in grey) to make one diamond. 

Loop the grey code to create a fun pattern!
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 14_markdown_instruc:
Play around with the code for the diamond and see what other patterns you can make. 

Try changing how many degrees you turn and how many times you loop.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 2_markdown_instruct:
Here is the same puzzle that we just solved, but this time, we can only use one `move forward` block and one `turn` block this time.

Can you use a `repeat` to solve this puzzle?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 9_markdown_instruct: Draw a simple V (where both sides are 50 pixels) to complete the arrow.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 1_markdown_instr: You've used loops to draw shapes before, but now we're going to put loops inside of other loops! Put a `repeat` block around this whole stack of code to draw the pattern.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 10_markdown_inst: Loop this code 12 times to complete the pattern.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 11_markdown_inst: Loop this code 4 times to complete the pattern, turn 90 degrees after each circle.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 12_markdown_inst: Loop this code 12 times to complete the curls.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 2_markdown_instr:
Now loop the triangle 6 times. 

After each triangle, you'll need to turn 60 degrees before drawing the next.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 3_markdown_instr:
You'll need to loop your triangle 12 times to draw this pattern. 

Divide the number of degrees in a circle (360) by the number of shapes you're drawing (12) to figure out how far to turn after each shape.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 4_markdown_instr:
Loop this diamond 12 times to draw a flower!

Note: We'll use the same angle to loop 12 diamonds as we did for 12 triangles.  
How much do you need to turn after each shape?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 5_markdown_instr:
Fill in this building's windows using a nested loop. 

The windows are 20 pixels long and 20 pixels apart.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 6_markdown_instr:
This dinosaur has 8 spikes running up its tail.

Each spike is 30 pixels long. 

Loop the triangle 8 times, but make sure to jump forward after each one!
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 7_markdown_instr:
Loop this triangle 10 times to draw the sun. 

You'll need to move and turn after each triangle. 

You can figure out how much to turn by dividing the number of degrees in a circle by the number of triangles that make it up.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 8_markdown_instr:
Now let's add some grass to our picture. 

Each tuft of grass is 50 pixels apart.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 9_markdown_instr:
We'll finish this picture by adding our flower. 

Loop the diamond 12 times to draw the flower.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops Free Play_markdo: Free play, draw something cool with nested loops.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 11_markdown_instruc:
I wonder what's out there!

Help me fly around the yard and collect nectar only from the flowers that have some.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 13_markdown_instruc:
There's a lot happening here!

Use what you've learned to collect all of the nectar and then make the honey.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 14_markdown_instruc:
Let's put everything together!

Use what you've learned to help me collect nectar only from flowers that have it, using as few blocks as possible.  

Don't forget to make honey at the end.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 15_markdown_instruc:
This stair step pattern should look familiar.  

Can you collect nectar only from the flowers that have some, using as few blocks as possible?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 2_markdown_instruct:
I'm a hungry bee! 


Help me collect all of the nectar from the flowers using the fewest number of blocks.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 3_markdown_instruct:
Look at all of that nectar!

Help me collect the nectar and make the honey using as few blocks as you can.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 5_markdown_instruct:
These magic purple flowers change!

Each time you try the puzzle, purple flowers can have either 1 nectar or none at all...but you won't know the number until you run the code! 

Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. 
You must first check if the nectar is equal to 1 using the `if nectar` block.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals Assessment 1_markdo:
**Assessment:** Collect all of the nectar.  
Be careful not to try to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 1_markdown_instruction:
These blocks are really bugging me!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 10_markdown_instructio:
This puzzle is making me loopy! 

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 2_markdown_instruction:
Can you find the problem here?

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 3_markdown_instruction:
Ooh, this one stings!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 5_markdown_instruction:
That flower looks tasty! 

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.  
You can now use both run and step.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 6_markdown_instruction:
What a sweet challenge!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging 9_markdown_instruction:
"Bee" patient with this one!

You will need to fix a couple of things in this program to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Debugging Assessment 1_markdown_:
**Assessment:**  Now it's time to show what you know!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 1_markdown_instruction:
Functions are blocks of code that perform a task.  

Use the `get 2 nectar` function to collect the nectar from each flower.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 10_markdown_instructio:
Purple flowers change between either 1 or 0 nectar each time you run the puzzle.   

Create a function that collects nectar only from purple flowers that have nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 2_markdown_instruction:
Functions are blocks of code that perform a task.  

Use the `get 5` function to get 5 nectars at a time.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 4_markdown_instruction:
The `move and get nectar` function turns the bee, collects nectar, and then returns the bee to where it started.  

Use the function to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions Assessment 1_markdown_: **Assessment:** Use the given function to collect nectar from each flower.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Functions Assessment 2_markdown_: **Assessment:** Create a function to turn, move forward and make 3 honey, then return the bee to where it started and turn back.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 1_markdown_instruction:
Those flowers look tasty!

Collect nectar from each of the flowers using the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 13_markdown_instruction: **Assessment:** Collect all of the nectar using the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 3A_markdown_instruction: Use a `repeat` loop to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 3B_markdown_instruction: Now use the `repeat` block to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 4_markdown_instruction:
Such a busy bee!

Help Bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey with the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 4A_markdown_instruction:
How many times can loops help you in this puzzle?  

Loops are your friend! Use a few of them to complete this puzzle with the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 5_markdown_instruction:
The shape of this path is different from the others. 

Can you collect all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 7_markdown_instruction:
What a beautiful field of flowers!   

Help the bee visit each one.

Can you find a way to do it with fewer than 7 blocks?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 8_markdown_instruction:
These purple flowers have different amount of nectar each time you run the puzzle. 

Use the `while nectar` loop to collect all of the nectar. 

This loop will run as long as the condition is true, in this case `nectar > 0`.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Bee Loops Assessment 1_markdown_inst: **Assessment:** Use a `while` loop to collect all of the nectar from these flowers.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze 1_markdown_instruction:
Can you help me catch the naughty pig? 

Stack a couple of `move forward` blocks below the `when run` block and press "Run".
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze 12 - One Move Block_markdown_in:
Get the mean pig! But this time, you can only use one `move forward` block...

Ah, look closely - do you see any other blocks that can help you get there?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze 12_markdown_instruction:
Suddenly, a magical block appears!  With the `repeat` block, you can loop code over and over.

Can you get to the pig by creating a loop that uses only one `move forward` block inside of a `repeat`?
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze 13_markdown_instruction: Get me to the pig! You can only use one `move forward` block this time
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze 15_markdown_instruction: In this puzzle, two `repeat` loops will help you get to the pig with the fewest number of blocks!
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze Loops 18_markdown_instruction:
Get me to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!  

Try using one `repeat` loop inside of another to cut down on the amount of code you need.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze Loops 19_markdown_instruction:
Let's take this to another level! 

Use loops to get me to the sunflower with the fewest loops possible.
markdown_instructions.2-3 Maze Loops Assessment 1_markdown_ins: **Assessment:**  Get me to the sunflower using only 5 blocks!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 1_markdown_instruction: Help me finish drawing my box. (Each line is 300 pixels long)
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 10_markdown_instruction: Press "Run" to try the code. Then, repeat it enough times to complete the drawing. The colors will be different every time.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 11_markdown_instruction:
Complete the green lines.  

The lines are 300 pixels long and 15 pixels apart.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 2_markdown_instruction: Loop this code using the `repeat` block to complete the square.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 3.5_markdown_instruction:
Try to figure out what happens if you run this code (or just press "Run" and try it). 

Next, repeat the code enough times to complete the drawing!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 3_markdown_instruction:
This rectangular flower bed has a perimeter of 600.  
The long side has a length of 200. 

Draw the rectangle using as few blocks as possible.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 4_markdown_instruction:
How many degrees are in a circle?  

Loop the blocks to create a circle of colors.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 5_markdown_instruction: What can we replace "???" with to make sure that the zombie completes this drawing using the loop provided?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 6_markdown_instruction: This equilateral triangle has angles of 60, 60, and 60 degrees. Each side is 200 pixels. Complete the drawing.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 7_markdown_instruction:
This right triangle has angles of 30, 60, and 90 degrees.  The slanted side's length (length of the hypotenuse) is 200 pixels. 

Complete the drawing.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 8_markdown_instruction:
The halfway line on a soccer field is *perpendicular* to the sidelines.   
This rectangle has a perimeter of 800 pixels total, and it is 240 pixels long. How tall is it?   

Draw the bounds and the halfway line.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist 9_markdown_instruction:
Draw the right half of this image so that the design is symmetrical. 
The triangles are equilateral and have sides that are 50 pixels long.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Assessment 1_markdown_instruc: **Assessment:** Use a loop to draw the equilateral triangle. Each side is 300 pixels.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Free Draw 1_markdown_instruct: Free Draw!  Draw whatever you are inspired to create.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 1_markdown_instructi:
Draw this square using a loop.

Each side is 20 pixels long.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 10_markdown_instruct:
This code draws two rows of hexagons - loop the whole thing 4 times to draw the whole honeycomb. 

You'll need to jump back 120 pixels in your outermost loop to make sure the artist doesn't draw off the screen.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 11_markdown_instruct: How many times do you need to loop this to draw a half circle?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 12_markdown_instruct:
If you create another loop like this one, but turn left instead of right, what happens? 

Can you repeat all of that to draw this wave?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 13_markdown_instruct:
Now let's loop that whole thing four times to create this picture frame. Watch out for the corners - you can't just turn 90 degrees! 

If looping a 3 degree turn 60 times makes a half circle, which of these blocks of code will make an additional quarter circle for the corners?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 2_markdown_instructi:
If you place your square loop inside another loop, we call that a nested loop. 

What do you need to add as an outer loop to make sure all 15 squares line up next to each other?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 3_markdown_instructi: Now let's go one level deeper! We've nested that whole block of code into another loop, but you need to get the artist back in place to draw the next line. Which of these code blocks can you place at the end of the outermost loop to draw the whole grid?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 4_markdown_instructi:
This diamond has 50 pixel sides and angles of 120 and 60 degrees. 

Use a loop to draw it.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 5_markdown_instructi:
Repeat this code to make a row of 6 diamonds. 

Notice that we changed our diamond code to repeat 3 times instead of 2 - why do you think that is?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 6_markdown_instructi: How many times do you need to repeat this block to draw the full grid of diamonds?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 7_markdown_instructi: Let's modify the code from the last puzzle to make this more complex pattern. Notice how the diamonds overlap now, try changing the first "jump backwards" from 100 to 50 (half as far) - now how far should the artist go in the second "jump backwards"?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 8_markdown_instructi: Use a loop to draw this hexagon with 40 pixel sides and 60 degree angles.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 9.5_markdown_instruc:
Let's loop this code to draw two rows of hexagons. 

Notice how our second row is shifted to the right.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 9_markdown_instructi:
Now repeat this code 3 times and draw the whole row. 

Each hexagon is 80 pixels wide from the furthest points left to right.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns Free Play_markdown_i: Free play - try your hand at making a pattern of your own!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 1_markdown_instruct:
This cloud is blocking my view! 

Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud, and only get nectar if there's a flower.   
Be careful, it can change!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 2_markdown_instruct:
More clouds! 

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar.  

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 4_markdown_instruct:
Sometimes this cloud covers a flower, and sometimes it covers a honeycomb! 

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar only if it is a flower.  
Else, make honey (because it is a honeycomb).
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 5_markdown_instruct:
There will be either a flower or a honeycomb under each of those clouds!

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar if there is a flower.
Otherwise, make honey (because there is a honeycomb).
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 6_markdown_instruct:
I am not sure how much nectar this flower has, but I know it has either 1, 2, or 3 nectar. 

Combine the conditional blocks (`if` and/or `if/else`) to only get as much nectar as the flower has. 

Remember, the amount of nectar can change each time you run the puzzle!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 7_markdown_instruct:
These flowers can have 3, 2, or 1 nectar. 

Complete the `check purple flower` function and use it to collect all of the nectar at the flowers.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 8_markdown_instruct:
Write the function for `check flower make honey`. 

Your function should check if the purple flower has 3, 2, or 1 nectar and get all of the nectar. 
Then, move forward and make honey.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals Assessment 1_markdo:
**Assessment:** This cloud is either hiding a flower with one nectar or a honeycomb that needs one honey.  

Complete the `get nectar or make honey` function, then call it to collect the nectar or honey.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Debugging 1_markdown_instruction:
These blocks are really bugging me. 

Can you fix them?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Debugging 6_markdown_instruction:
The purple flower has a different amount of nectar each time you run the puzzle. 

Fix the blocks to get all of the nectar from the flower each time.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 2_markdown_instruct:
Collect all of the nectar from each flower. 

Use a nested loop.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 4_markdown_instruct:
Collect all of the nectar from each flower and make honey at the honeycomb. 

Use a nested loop.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops Assessment 1_markdo: **Assessment:** Collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey using loops.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze 7_markdown_instruction:
Get the zombie to the sunflower quickly!  

Can you solve the puzzle in fewer than 11 blocks?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze 9_markdown_instruction:
Now we have a new block called `repeat until`.  
This will let us keep looping commands until the zombie gets the sunflower.  

Use the new `repeat until` block to solve this puzzle in as few commands as possible.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Assessment 1_markdown_instructi: **Assessment:** Get to the sunflower using as few blocks as possible.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 1_markdown_instruc: Use the `repeat until` block to get the zombie to the sunflower.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 10_markdown_instru:
Can you add just 3 blocks to help the zombie solve a more complex maze? 

If you do it right, he can walk any curvy path no matter the length!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 2_markdown_instruc: Use the `repeat until` block to get the zombie to the sunflower.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 3_markdown_instruc: Use the `if` block to help me decide when to turn.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 4_markdown_instruc: Ok, solve this one just like the last puzzle, but you need to remember how you used the `if` and `repeat until` blocks together.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 5_markdown_instruc:
"Me want sunflower!"  

Use an `if` statement to get the zombie to the sunflower with the fewest number of blocks.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 6_markdown_instruc:
"Eat sunflower!"

Use an `if` statement to get the zombie to the sunflower with the fewest number of blocks.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 7_markdown_instruc: The solution to this puzzle isn't very different, but watch out for the chompers!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 8_markdown_instruc:
The `if/else` block checks a condition, and then does one thing OR another. 

Use this new block to get me to the sunflower.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 9_markdown_instruc:
One more practice puzzle with the `if/else` block!

Trace it with your finger to see if you can figure it out on your first try.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals Assessment 1_markd: **Assessment:** Use a `repeat until` and an `if/else` block to get me to the sunflower in as few blocks as possible.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 1_markdown_instruction: Complete the code to draw these triangles.  The first one is done for you.  Hint:  3 triangles in a 360 degree rotation.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 11_markdown_instruction:
Can you draw these 10 squares of this sidewalk using a nested loop? 

Each square is 30 pixels.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 12_markdown_instruction: Can you draw these 36 triangles using a nested loop?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 2_markdown_instruction:
Now nest this loop inside another loop to draw 10 triangles.  
This is called a "nested" loop.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 3_markdown_instruction:
Create a sun by nesting the starter code in another loop.

To get this cool design with a hollow center, you'll need to jump forward by the length of the triangle before turning.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 5_markdown_instruction: Loop the given code to create a windmill.
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 6_markdown_instruction: Can you draw a hexagon by looping the triangle code?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 7_markdown_instruction:
Loop this design 10 times. 

How much do you have to turn each time you loop?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 8_markdown_instruction:
Loop this shape 6 times. 

How much do you have to turn each time you loop?
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 9_markdown_instruction: Draw the teeth in the alligator's mouth!
markdown_instructions.4-5 Nested Loops Assessment 1_markdown_i: **Assessment:** Use a nested loop to complete the design.
markdown_instructions.4-5 While Loops 1_markdown_instruction: Move me to the hole and fill it with two shovelfuls of dirt, using the `fill` block.
markdown_instructions.4-5 While Loops 2_markdown_instruction: Move me to the pile of dirt and remove it with 5 shovel scoops, using the `remove 1` block.
markdown_instructions.4-5 While Loops 3_markdown_instruction:
Use as few blocks as possible to complete this puzzle!  

Move me to the pile and remove all the dirt, then move to the hole and fill it completely.
markdown_instructions.4-5 While Loops 4_markdown_instruction:
Wow, look at that! 

I don't know how many shovelfuls of dirt this hole needs.  
Can you write a program that keeps using the `fill` block until the ground is even?

markdown_instructions.AllTheThings Applab - Turtle move with b: # Please sign in to test applab levels (By design, applab levels only work if signed in. Normally, we make people sign in, but this is only enforceable for a whole script and would be annoying to do for the allthethings script). # Your First Interactive App! A new group of commands has been added to the toolbox called **UI Controls** (User Interface Controls) which are commands that let you interact with, and respond to, the user of your app. To keep it simple, we'll start with just two commands: * `onEvent` which let's you run a function in response to some event occuring (such as a button click) * `button` which puts a button on the screen # Do This You will replicate the small app, shown below, which makes the turtle move with a button click. You will do three things: * Add a `button` * Add an `onEvent` block * Add `moveForward` inside the the onEvent function block Here's what you should do - you can come back to watch this as many times as you need to get it right.
markdown_instructions.AllTheThings: Pixelation - Lesson 15 - C:
# Color Pixelation: Task 1
**Directions:**

* We start you with the 4x2 image Maddie was creating, but we've left out the last two squares. 
* Finish off the image by figuring out which two colors are missing and encode them.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 1 - Add Button_markdown_ins:
# Getting Started - Add a button

You'll need a button on your home screen to go to your new screen. You can make a new button in two ways. 

1. If you like the style of the "Dogs" button you can make a copy of it. Click the button and then click "Duplicate".

	![](https://images.code.org/171aa97d90014f66f999ecf929b672c0-image-1504289310310.08.10 AM.png)

2. You can also make a new button from scratch by dragging it in from the Design Toolbox.

	![](https://images.code.org/501c9ddd3e5b737df5b9cf053ae198a7-image-1504289359851.09.09 AM.png)

3. Click and drag to move your new button where you want it.

3. Once you have a new button give it a clear name, "catButton". You can also change its text to read "Cats!".

	![](https://images.code.org/87586b18b001fae0001d2243f6d09889-image-1504289448320.10.14 AM.png)
    
4. There's lots of other ways you can change the look of your button. Experiment with the full menu of options.

5. Once you're done run your app to make sure your button appears. Then click "Finish" to move on to learn how to make your button actually work.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 1 - Add Event_markdown_inst:
# Getting Started - onEvent

You're back in "Code Mode". You'll notice there's already a bit of code in this app. This `onEvent()` block runs some code when the `dogButton` is clicked. You're going to need a second `onEvent()` block to make your button work. There's two ways to do this.

1. From Code Mode you can drag in the block 

	![](https://images.code.org/c1ca564880152242c3bf92b2b9ad4fca-image-1504290427563.26.56 AM.png)
    
2. From Design Mode your button has an "Events" tab. Click 'Insert and show code' to add the code.

	![](https://images.code.org/90d6c0cb723ee4317244f99dcfbd3a66-image-1504290568475.29.18 AM.png)
    
3. Use the drop down to make sure you're making the event respond to the "catButton".

	![](https://images.code.org/ebef61f18259a2fb0d8addb90d9d8ba4-image-1504290674099.31.03 AM.png)
    
4. The `setScreen()` block changes the screen. Drag this block inside your `onEvent()` block and choose your `catScreen` from the list.

	![](https://images.code.org/00433d32665ec6f2aa6a0caac2626568-image-1504290788639.33.02 AM.png)
    
5. Run your app. If everything worked correctly your cat button should now take you to your cat screen when you click it. When you're ready move on to learn how to add sounds to your app!
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 1 - Add Screen_markdown_ins:
# Getting Started - Add a cats screen

1. You're going to make a cats screen. This is "Design Mode" where you can add and edit screens. To add a screen click the screen dropdown and select "New screen".

	![expandable](https://images.code.org/4e90c1d897ede63403a1351f5ec3bfae-image-1504288061907.47.33 AM.png) 

2. Then name your new screen "catScreen". 

	![expandable](https://images.code.org/966a2563aaf8a59a983fe6417d01dae9-image-1504288205242.49.33 AM.png)
    
3. Finally, choose the cats background image of your screen

	![expandable](https://images.code.org/ff8509146b8a249973498af63f41b08d-image-1504288758611.51.40 AM.png)
    
Once you have added your new screen hit "Finish" to learn how to add buttons to navigate to the screen.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 1 - Add Sound_markdown_inst:
# Getting Started - Add Sound

App Lab can play sound too. You'll need to use the `playSound()` block to do it.

1. Drag a `playSound()` block into your `onEvent`. This will make the sound play when your user clicks the button. Then click "Choose..." from the menu.

	![](https://images.code.org/9c84293859317f7ae46391a28c5a51e7-image-1504291688560.47.41 AM.png)

2. Go through the "Sound Library" and find the sounds you want. There's tons!

	![](https://images.code.org/5393762b4f31fa4f09040ca8b09ca91c-image-1504291692587.47.52 AM.png)

3. Run your app to check out how your sounds work.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 1 - Build Your Adventure_ma:
# Build Your Adventure

Use this blank project to build your project. To get you started there's already a home screen with a couple of buttons. If you want you can **quickly make copies of screens** to build out your world. What will you create?!

When you're done you can "Share" your work with a friend by phone or with a link. Create your own account to keep building in App Lab!
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 1 - Template_markdown_instr:
# Getting Started - Try this app

Before you build your own Choose Your Own Adventure app, practice using AppLab by building this one about a visit to a pet shop. To get started, click "Run" and then navigate to the "Dogs" screen. Once you've made it there click "Finish" to move on.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 1 - Try App_markdown_instru:
# Getting Started - Try this app

Before you build your own Choose Your Own Adventure app, practice using AppLab by building this one about a visit to a pet shop. To get started, click "Run" and then navigate to the "Dogs" screen. Once you've made it there click "Finish" to move on.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - Edit place1 2_markdown_:
Think about how you want your adventure to continue on this screen. Then add some text to tell your story!

1. Use the screen selector to choose the screen you just made ([Show me where](#triggercallout=selector))
2. Drag a new "text area" onto your screen to add it. ([Show me where](#triggercallout=textArea))
3. Drag the bottom right corner of your text area to change its size.
4. Change the text to tell your user what happens on this screen. Then change the color of your text if you want!

Click "Run" and then "Finish" to move on.

![expandable](https://images.code.org/8ba0d4f0eccaf83163e86d10eec3a291-image-1505766539456.gif) Click to see a GIF of these steps
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - Edit place1_markdown_in:
On the last screen you gave your character a choice between to actions or places. Pick one of them and start making a screen for it!

1. In the screen selector choose "New screen..." ([Show me where](#triggercallout=selector))
2. Change the "id" of the screen to something clear, for example the name of the new location ([Show me where](#triggercallout=idChange))
3. You can switch back and forth between your two screens from the screen selector. ([Show me where](#triggercallout=selector))
4. You can select the "background-color" of your screen if you like.

Click "Run" and then "Finish" to move on and start adding to your screen.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - Edit startScreen_markdo:
Welcome to App Lab! Right now you're in **Design Mode** where you can personalize the look of your app. Get your adventure started by picking a fun title!

1. Click the title of your app. ([Show me where](#triggercallout=titleCallout))
2. Change the "text" to pick whatever name you like! ([Show me where](#triggercallout=designMenu))
3. Scroll down the menu to change the color of your title ([Show me where](#triggercallout=changeTextColor))

Once you like the look of your title hit "Run" once to make sure it's looking good. Then hit "Finish" to move on!

![expandable](https://images.code.org/47c8fc2986226beaa39e382bc0759797-image-1505765264098.com-gif-maker.gif) Click here to see all three steps in a GIF
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - Edit startScreen2_markd:
Nice work! Time to start filling in your story.

1. Click the story text on this screen. ([Show me where](#triggercallout=storyText))
2. Fill in your story ([Show me where](#triggercallout=editStoryText))
3. Explore the different properties you can change in the menu. Personalize this screen's look! ([Show me where](#triggercallout=changeTextColor))

Hit "Run" once to make everything looks good. Then hit "Finish" to move on!
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - Template_markdown_instr:
# Getting Started - Try this app

Before you build your own Choose Your Own Adventure app, practice using AppLab by building this one about a visit to a pet shop. To get started, click "Run" and then navigate to the "Dogs" screen. Once you've made it there click "Finish" to move on.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - Try App_markdown_instru: # Getting Started - Try this app You're going to build a "Choose Your Own Adventure" app by extending this project. To get you started you already have the parts of your project outlined in blue. Hit "Run" and click through what's already been created for you. Once you see how the project already works hit "Finish" to start making it yours.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - Try Cat Commander_markd:
This is what the code for Cat Commander looks like. Take one minute to scroll through the code and see if you can understand how it works. Talk about it with a partner. What patterns do you see? 

Once you're done, move on by clicking "Run" then "Finish", to learn to build your own adventure.
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - add Button_markdown_ins:
Now you have two screens, but no way to get between them. Time to start adding buttons!

1. Use the screen selector to go back to your "startScreen" ([Show me where](#triggercallout=selector))
2. Drag a button onto the screen ([Show me where](#triggercallout=dragButton))
3. Give your button a clear "id" that describes what it does ([Show me where](#triggercallout=changeButtonID))
4. Change the "text" of your button to describe where it will take the user.
5. Personalize your button's other properties like "text color" or "background color".

Click "Run" then "Finish" to move on and start writing the code that will make your button work

![expandable](https://images.code.org/43f2678e4748a1fa09556f75cad65e97-image-1505766882756.gif) Click to see a GIF of all steps
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - add images_markdown_ins:
You now know everything you need to make a simple Choose Your Own Adventure app, but you can add so much more! If you want to add images to your screen it's easy!

1. In another tab in your browser go online and find an image you want to use
2. Right click the image and save its URL (usually "Copy link address" or "Copy image URL")
3. Back in App Lab go to Design Mode
4. Drag an "image" element onto your screen
5. Paste the URL you copied into the "image" property

"Run" your app once to test it. Then hit "Finish" to move to learn to add sounds.

![expandable](https://images.code.org/5b977b1c127b3fcb1761aadcb74c79e8-image-1505772215256.gif) Click to see GIF of all steps
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - add more buttons 2_mark:
Time to add a second button and write the code to make it work.

1. Drag a second button onto your "startScreen" and give it a clear "id"
2. Change the text and color of your button
3. In Code Mode drag in a second `onEvent()` block and drag a `setScreen()` inside of it
4. Set the "id"s of your `onEvent()` and `setScreen()` blocks to the button and screens you added

If everything worked you should now have a second button that changes the screen. "Run" your app and hit "Finish" if it worked.

![expandable](https://images.code.org/33d1a6d2dcc81ed8ecd0966d2f0682ca-image-1505770427380.gif) Click to see a GIF of all steps
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - add more buttons_markdo:
If this is going to be a real Choose Your Own Adventure, you're need to add some more choices! Start by adding a screen for the second choice your player could make.

1. Use the screen selector to add a new screen. Give it a clear "id".
2. Set the "background color" of your screen
3. Add a "Text Area" to your screen describing what happens on it.

Click "Run" then "Finish" to move on. You'll add another button and write the code to make it work.

![expandable](https://images.code.org/f1c83578a245d832c94c78aeba6ef317-image-1505768404048.gif) Click to see a GIF of all steps
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - add onEvent_markdown_in: This is Code Mode where you write the code of your app. You're going to add code that looks like this picture. 1. Click and drag an "onEvent" block into your workspace ([Show me where](#triggercallout=onEvent)) 2. Use the left dropdown to pick your button's ID 3. Click and drag a "setScreen" block inside the "onEvent" block ([Show me where](#triggercallout=setScreen)) 4. Use the dropdown to pick your new screen's ID Your app now switches screens! Try it out yourself by hitting "Run". Then "Finish" to move on. ![expandable](https://images.code.org/b9970c3478dfb15e7531034d26fbcc40-image-1505767231404.gif) Click to see all steps in a GIF
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - add sound_markdown_inst: You can add sound to your app too! Add them outside an `onEvent()` to play from the start of the adventure (good for background music) or inside an `onEvent()` to play when that button is clicked (good for "Win" / "Lose" sounds). 1. Drag a `playSound()` block into your program 2. Click the dropdown, then "Choose...", then "Sound Library" to find the library of sounds built into App Lab 3. Try out the "Background" category for longer songs that will play for your entire adventure. 4. Hit "Choose" to select the sound you like. 5. You can also drag code inside an `onEvent` block to play sound only when an event happens. Shorter sounds work better here. Run your app. There should be sound playing now too!
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 2 - finish and share_markdo:
Congrats on finishing your Hour of Code! You can share your work with friends! Click "Share" to get a link or even text it to them.

You can keep working on your project here. Whenever your friends go to the link you shared they'll get the latest version you made. How far will you build your adventure?

markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 3 - onEvent before_markdown:

markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 3 - onEvent intro_markdown_:
Blocks placed inside the new `onEvent()` block will only run when you `"click"` the `"bigButton"`. Add code so the button will make the screen's `"background-color"` turn `"green"`. Remember to use double-quotes `"` for colors. Click the picture to see how.

markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 3 - onEvent mouseInOut_mark:

![expandable](https://images.code.org/5cd0c24b0f7f855daa2225a4b6a08087-image-1505932139152.gif)
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 3 - onEvent mouseOut_markdo:
The `"mouseout"` event fires when your mouse moves out of a button. Write code that will set the screen's `"background-color"` back to `"black"` and set the button's `"text"` to `"Off!"` when the mouse moves out of the button. Remember to use double quotes `"`. Click the picture to see how.

![expandable](https://images.code.org/a3403900844f631cc2579539c8d68ed1-image-1505937421979.gif)
markdown_instructions.AppLab Intro 3 - onEvent mouseOver_markd:
`"click"` is just one type of event. `"mouseover"` events run when your mouse is over a button, even if you don't click it. Add code to set the `"background-color"` of the screen to `"black"` when the mouse is over the `"offButton"`. Click the picture to see how.

![expandable](https://images.code.org/756e2c5ee19fd94963ca364fd46bcbd8-image-1505935772425.gif)

markdown_instructions.Artist Inspiration_markdown_instruction: **Free-Play Inspiration:** You've now learned everything you need to know to make a pattern like this! If this picture inspires you, try to make something similar. Otherwise, create something all your own. Notice: We've used the `set alpha` block to make the "petals" fade toward the outside.
markdown_instructions.Bergeron Robot Maze1_markdown_instructio:
Can you help me catch the naughty pig? 

Stack a couple of `move forward` blocks below the `when run` block and press "Run".
markdown_instructions.Big Game Animation 1_markdown_instructio: Now that you've learned to write simple linear functions, let's work on using them to add some movement to our game. Click "Run" to see what your game can currently do (not much!), update any variables you like, and then click finish to move on.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Animation 2_markdown_instructio:
The `update-target` function takes the target's current x value, and returns an updated value.

Complete `update-target` so that it adds to the x value each time it is called. The more you add to x, the faster the target will go.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Animation 3_markdown_instructio:
The `update-danger` function should work just like `update-target`, except that the danger should move from the right side over towards the left.

Complete `update-danger` to make the danger fly across the screen.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Animation 4_markdown_instructio:
At this point in your game your danger should run across the screen from right to left, and your target should run across from left to right.

They don't ever come back on screen once they've left, but we'll take care of that later.

Take a minute to make sure your game is working like you want it to, and then click "Finish" to move on.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Booleans 1_markdown_instruction: When you last worked on your game we got our target and danger sprites to fly across the screen, but they never come back. Click "Run" to see how your game is currently working, and then click finish and we'll work on making those sprites reappear on screen after they've left.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Booleans 2_markdown_instruction:
Now that your `onscreen?` function is checking `safe-left?` and `safe-right?` we need to fix those functions.

When we used them for Sam the Bat we wanted to prevent Sam from leaving the screen, but now we want the Target and Danger to actually go all the way off screen before returning to the opposite side.

Go to the "Functions" section of the toolbox and complete the `safe-left?` function so that it returns *true* if the sprite's x coordinate is greater than -50.

If you're successful you should see the Danger go all the way off the left side before returning on the right side.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Booleans 3_markdown_instruction:
Now that you've got `safe-left?` working, let's fix `safe-right?`

It should take in a sprite's x coordinate and return true if that coordinate is less than 450.

Once your `safe-right?` is complete you should see the Target go off the right side of the screen and return on the left.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Booleans 4_markdown_instruction:
We've provided a couple of empty functions for `safe-left?` and `safe-right?` The first thing you need to do is complete the `onscreen?` function so that it checks whether both `safe-left?` and `safe-right?` are true.

**TIP** - even after you add `safe-left?` and `safe-right?` your sprites won't return to the screen - why do you think that is?
markdown_instructions.Big Game Booleans 5_markdown_instruction: At this point your Danger should run across the screen from right to left, your Target should run across from left to right, and they should both return to the opposite side, repeatedly. Take a minute to make sure your game is working like you want it to, and then click "Finish" to move on.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Collision 1_markdown_instructio: At this point you've programmed a video game with a moving Target and Danger, both of which return to the screen once they've left, and a Player that responds to keyboard input. Click "Run" to see how your game is currently working, and then we'll dig into the final missing piece - collision detection!
markdown_instructions.Big Game Collision 3_markdown_instructio:
Let's fix this `distance` function so our collision detection works properly.

Use the Distance Formula, so the distance function returns the distance between the player's center coordinates (px, py) and another sprite's center coordinates (cx, cy).

We've provided a working `line-length` function to help you out.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Collision 4_markdown_instructio:
The `distance` function returns the distance between two sprites.

Complete the `collide?` function so that it returns *true* if the distance between two points is less than 100 pixels apart.

If you're successful, your sprites will instantly collide - why do you think that is?
markdown_instructions.Big Game Final_markdown_instruction:
You made it!

At this point your game should be fully functioning, take some time to enjoy your new game and make any final tweaks to it.

When you're happy with the final product, click Finish and you'll have an opportunity to share a link to your game.

Good work!
markdown_instructions.Big Game Player 1_markdown_instruction:
We're getting really close to a finished game!

Last time you worked on your game, you used booleans to make your Target and Danger return to the screen once they've left. Click "Run" to see how your game looks right now, and then we'll get to making your Player move up and down.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Player 2_markdown_instruction:
To move the player up and down, we'll need to use a conditional block to figure out which key is pressed and respond accordingly.

Computers read keypresses as numeric key codes - the up arrow is **38** and the down arrow is **40**. You can lookup other key codes in your student workbook.

Edit the `update-player` function so the player moves up when the up arrow (keycode 38) is pressed, and moves down (keycode 40) when the down arrow is pressed.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Vars 1_markdown_instruction: Let's get started on your Big Game! Here you'll see a whole bunch of placeholder code that you'll eventually replace with your own, but for now we're only going to worry about defining variables. Click "Run" to see what the game looks like with the default values.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Vars 2_markdown_instruction: The first step to making this game your own is to give it a good Title. Click edit on the `title` and `subtitle` variables and change them to something new.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Vars 3_markdown_instruction: Now let's set the background for your new game. Edit the `bg` variable and select a new background Image from the dropdown.
markdown_instructions.Big Game Vars 4_markdown_instruction: Awesome! Now you can update the variables for your Player, Target, and Danger. Feel free to play with all of the variables at this point to make your game look like you'd like it to. Click "Finish" when you're done.

markdown_instructions.CSD Hackathon Pt 1_markdown_instruction:
# MS Hackathon: Fancy Drawing

The blocks you've been provided are those that a student in CS Discoveries would likely have available after a week or so of using Game Lab. No sprites yet, but you've **just been introduced to some powerful programming constructs like generating random numbers, storing values in a variable, and looping.** You'll also be pretty familiar with the drawing commands at this point.

# Do This

* Using only the tools provided to you, **make something awesome!!**
* The likely project at this point would be an **animated card** but feel free to go other directions if you like.
* **Avoid complex variable arithmetic** if you can. You "don't know it" yet.
* **Avoid referencing the iterator in your for loops**. At this point it's just a repeat loop.

markdown_instructions.CSD U1 - PixFilter 1x1 Filter_markdown_i:
# Filtering Images
If you've ever used Instragram you've probably encountered an image filter. Image filters read in each pixel, process it in some way, and the return the filtered pixel. In this tool we're going to start by filtering just a single pixel before moving on to a full image.

Youll notice there are three drop downs under the picture. A red replace, a green replace, and a blue replace. Next to it are drop downs for the colors. How many bits are we working with? Yes, were working with 3. We also learned that the bits control the colors. First bit controls R, second bit controls G, third bit controls B.


# Do This
Try changing the color drop downs next to replace. Based on how the bits change, can you formulate what replace is doing? Talk to your partner and see if you can figure it out.
markdown_instructions.CSD U1 - PixFilter 1x1 intro_markdown_in:
# 3 Bit Colors
Each pixel is a square on a screen that emits light. Each pixel can have a certain number of bits assigned to it, and bits per pixel determine the colors that can be rendered.

In this tool we're using 3 bits to define the one large black pixel. The first bit affects the red tint. The second bit affects the green tint. The third bit affects the blue tint.

# Do This

* Click the "Run" button to start the widget
* Click on the light bulbs to turn on or off each color and see what happens to your pixel
* See how many different colors you can create with just three bits
* Write down the binary associated with each color you come up with
markdown_instructions.CSD U1 - PixFilter Filter Intro_markdown:
# Filtering Pixels
If you've ever used Instagram you've probably encountered an image filter. Image filters read in each pixel, process it in some way, and the return the filtered pixel. In this tool we're going to start by filtering just a single pixel before moving on to a full image.

# Do This

* Try changing the color drop downs in the Filter section
* Click on the top row of lightbulbs in the Diagram section to see how the filter will convert the input (top bulbs) to the output (bottom bulbs)
* Look at how the numbers in the Binary section reflect changes to the colors
* Based on how the bits change, can you formulate what replace is doing? Talk to your partner and see if you can figure it out.
* Complete the Level 2 table in your Activity Guide

* Click on the top row of lightbulbs in the Diagram section to see how the filter will convert the input (top bulbs) to the output (bottom bulbs)

markdown_instructions.CSD U1 - PixFilter Mario_markdown_instru:
# Combining Filters

Sometimes you'll need to filter more than one pixel to get the color change that you want.

# Do This
Check out Mario, he's lookin' pretty good in his red hat and overalls. Your job it to set up the filter so he looks like Luigi, with a green hat and overalls.

* First, determine which bit(s) needs to change in order to the change you want
* Once you've figured out which bit needs changing, set the filter dropdown appropriately

_How many tries did it take you to find the right filter?_
markdown_instructions.CSD U1 - PixFilter Mushroom_markdown_ins:
# Filtering Images
Now that we've seen how a single pixel can be filtered to change its color, let's try applying a filter to an image made of multiple pixels. The filter you create will be applied to each pixel in the image - and you still have the light bulbs available to experiment with how your filter will work with individual colors.


# Do This
Here's a picture of a red mushroom - you're going to try and turn it into a yellow mushroom.

* First, determine which bit needs to change in order to turn red into yellow
* Once you've figured out which bit needs changing, use the filter dropdowns to make all of the red areas turn yellow
* After you've got the filter working so that the red has turned yellow, see if you can come up with filters that turn the mushroom other colors

_How many tries did it take you to find the right filter?_

markdown_instructions.CSD U2 HTML Adding Paragraphs Template_m:
# Add Text to the Body

When you start any Web Lab project it will automatically add `<!DOCTYPE>`, `<html>`, `<head>`, and `<body>` tags to your project. When you add content to your projects you'll need to do it between the `<body>` and `</body>` tags since it should be part of the body of your webpage.

# Do This

* Write three separate sentences about any topic you like inside of the body tags of your web page
* Hit "Refresh and Save" if you don't see the changes in the Preview area
* Compare your work with a neighbor. Make sure you're placing code in the same place.

markdown_instructions.CSD U2 Info Page Content_markdown_instru:
# Adding Your Content

You should now have found a handful of websites that you can use to help make your case for the cause you've chosen. If not, keep on researching! Otherwise it's time to start structuring the content of your page.

For all of the content you find externally, you'll need to provide attribution to the original creator. For now, just include the url of the site where you found it in parenthesis. For example

* According to the ASPCA only 10% of animals entering shelters have been spayed or neutered (http://www.aspca.org/animal-homelessness).
* Kill shelters euthanize 2.7 million animals per year (http://www.aspca.org/animal-homelessness).

# Do This

The specifics of your page layout will depend on your topics and goals, but in general you should create the following structure

* A first level header with a catchy title for your page
* A second level header for each separate argument to support your cause
* Paragraphs of content under each second level header
* The urls of any sites where you found information
* Don't worry about styling right now you are just getting the content

markdown_instructions.CSD U3 - Simple Counter Predict_markdown:
# The Counter Pattern

This pattern is one of the most important ones in all of programming. 

![](https://images.code.org/83af2e40443ab294ba635f2a01a48ac7-image-1465506512065.06.56 PM.png)
    
It is used to increase the value of a variable by 1. You might call it the **counter pattern** since it can be used to make a variable that counts up. You'll use this pattern a lot, especially with the draw loop. Let's see what that looks like.

# Do This

This program creates a variable `counter` and then uses the **counter pattern** to make it count up. When you run the program what do you think you'll see on the screen?

* **Read the program** and make a prediction of what the output will be.
* **Run the program** to check your prediction.
* **Discuss with a neighbor**. Can you explain what you observed?

markdown_instructions.CSD U3 - Sprites - Sprite v Rect_markdow:
# Sprites vs Rect

Curently sprites and rectangles seem really similar. It will become clear later on why sprites are more powerful than basic shapes. Before you get there though it is important to call out a major difference in the way sprites and rectangles draw.

# Do This
Can you will figure out the difference by just trying this?

* Create a rectangle with a width and height of 30
* Set the fill for the rectangle to a different color than gray (So its clear which is the rectangle)
* Create a sprite and give it the same x and y values as you gave the rectangle
* Make sure to call `drawSprites` in the draw loop
* Run the program
* Can you see the difference?
markdown_instructions.CSD U3 - complex - key up and down_markd:
# Responding to a Single Click

Earlier we learned that `keyWentDown` and `keyWentUp` can be used to respond to a keypress a single time. The blocks `mouseWentUp` and `mouseWentDown` allow you to do that for the mouse!

# Do This

Let's make a simple game that counts how many times you've clicked. We've already provided a variable `clicks` that you can use to track how many times the user has clicked.

* Add a conditional that checks if the mouse went down.
* Inside your conditional, add to the `clicks` variable.

_Challenge: Can you add a sprite that responds to `mouseWentDown` as well? Add an image of your choice and increase the sprite's size each time the mouse is clicked._

markdown_instructions.CSD U3 - complex - mouse down_markdown_i:
# Mouse Clicks

Keypresses are great, but sometimes you want users to interact through mouse clicks. There's a new block called `mouseDown` which, similar to `keyDown`, checks whether the left or right mouse buttons is being pressed. If you are using a computer with a mouse or trackpad that has only one button, you'll want to always use `mouseDown("left")`. 

# Do This
Here's a program that drops a balloon down the screen - you're going to program the mouse button to raise the balloon back up while it's clicked.

* Add an if else statment that checks for `mouseDown`.
* Inside the conditional, move the balloon up one pixel if the mouse is down. Otherwise, move the balloon down.

_Hint: You'll need to move the code that drops the balloon for this to work - you only want it to run if `mouseDown` is `false`_

_Challenge: Can you make the balloon drift randomly to the left and right as it rises and falls?_

# mouseDidMove

We can also use Boolean expressions to check whether or not the mouse has moved. The `mouseDidMove` block will return `false` if the mouse is still, but `true` if the mouse has been moving.

# Do This
Right now, this program just displays a salt shaker sprite. You'll need to use `mouseDidMove` so that you can "shake" the salt by moving the mouse back and forth.

* Add a conditional that checks if `mouseDidMove`.
* If the conditional is true, rotate the salt sprite randomly to the left or right.

_Challenge: Can you keep track of how many times the `mouseDidMove` shakes the salt, and then rotate it right side up after 100 shakes?_

markdown_instructions.CSD U3 - images - first sprite with imag: # Images Rectangles are great, but if you're going to make animations and games that really look great, you'll need some way to add more interesting images to your sprites. Once you have created a sprite you can **use the `setAnimation()` command to change the look of your sprite from a rectangle to a picture.** The blocks make this super easy to do as the names of all the images you have loaded in the animation tab show up in the `setAnimation()` dropdown. markdown_instructions.CSD U3 - images - scale_markdown_instruc:
# Upload your own image

So the image you uploaded probably was not the size you wanted was it? You can fix that!  There is a property for sprites called `scale`.  **Scale controls the width and the height of the sprite at once.** Using scale is better than  using width and height for images because...
1. It's one property instead of two.
2. You keep the image ratio and it doesn't distort it.

**To make the image smaller you want to use a scale less than 1. To make the image bigger you want to use a number greater than 1. A scale of 1 would keep it the same.**

# Do This

* Resize your kite using `scale` to better fit the picture.

It works best if it has a clear background. * Open the animations tab. * Click * Click * Select a file from your computer. * Rename your image so it has a name that is easy to remember. To rename it click the text below the image. * Set the kite sprite to display your image. Don't worry if your kite image is too big! You'll learn how to fix that in the next level.

# Visible

Now that you have conditionals and images sometimes it appropriate to hide the image for a while and then show it again. You can do this using the `visible` property. The visible property is a little different than some of the other properties you have seen in the past. It is a boolean value. So visible is either true or false. By default visible is set to true.


# Do This

markdown_instructions.CSD U3 - sprites - motiviation_markdown_:
# How Many Variables?

In the last lesson you learned how to use the **counter pattern** (`x = x + 1`, `x = x - 0.5`, `x = x - 1`, etc.) to create smooth animations. Using this pattern in many different ways allows you to create interesting and complex animations.

Watch the animation here. With a partner discuss: 

* How many counter variables would you need to create to make this animation? What are they used to animate?
* What would you name your variables?
* What are the challenges of using counter variables in a scene like this?

# Change Player Animations

Right now your player is always facing the same direction. You can make things look a lot more realistic by switching between animations. Your player should switch between a left-facing and right-facing animation depending on which key was last pressed. Remember, you can quickly copy and edit animations inside the Animation Tab.

# Do This

* Inside the Animation Tab copy the animation of your player sprite.
* Flip each frame of the new animation so that the sprite is facing in the opposite direction.
* Rename your new animation.
* Use the `setAnimation` command inside the `movePlayer` function so that the player changes the direction it is facing when the "left" and "right" arrows are pressed.

markdown_instructions.CSD U3 AnimationsMulti defender template:
# Play and Pause

You can use the `sprite.play` and `sprite.pause` commands to play and pause a sprite's animation. If the animation is already playing or paused, using these commands twice in a row has no effect.  There's one important exception, however, which is that **play will restart a non-looping animation if it has finished**. We're going to look at some cool behavior this lets us create.

# Do This

* Use the `sprite.play` command after each of your `setAnimation` commands. This will restart the walk animations as long as the keys are pressed.

# Play and Pause

You can use the `sprite.play` and `sprite.pause` commands to play and pause a sprite's animation. If the animation is already playing or paused, using these commands twice in a row has no effect.  There's one important exception, however, which is that **play will restart a non-looping animation if it has finished**. We're going to look at some cool behavior this lets us create.

# Do This

* Use the `sprite.play` command after each of your `setAnimation` commands. This will restart the walk animations as long as the keys are pressed.

By default your animations keep replaying in a loop. You can have your animation only play once by clicking this button below your animation.

markdown_instructions.CSD U3 AnimationsMulti play pause_markdo:
# Play and Pause

You can use the `sprite.play` and `sprite.pause` commands to play and pause a sprite's animation. If the animation is already playing or paused, using these commands twice in a row has no effect.  There's one important exception, however, which is that **play will restart a non-looping animation if it has finished**. We're going to look at some cool behavior this lets us create.

# Do This

* Use the `sprite.play` command after each of your `setAnimation` commands. This will restart the walk animations as long as the keys are pressed.

markdown_instructions.CSD U3 Background Experiment_markdown_in:
# Background
We could draw a 400 pixel white square each time the `draw()` loop runs, but there's actually a built-in command that works even better. The `background()` block just takes one input, the color of your background, and fills the whole canvas with that color. The nice thing about using `background()` instead of `rect()` is that it will fill the screen regardless of how big it is, making your code more flexible and usable in more scenarios (like when you get a new phone with a bigger screen).

# Do This
Place the `background()` block inside your `draw()` loop before any other shapes are drawn. Choose a background color of your choice and then test your code to make sure it only shows a single rectangle at a time.

markdown_instructions.CSD U3 Compound Nested Challenge_markdow:
# Challenge: Checking for Multiple Conditions
_Check with your teacher before taking on this challenge._


So far we've looked at a lot of ways to check if a single condition is true, but often a program needs to check the state of many conditions simultaneously before making a decision. For this challenge, let's assume the following scenario:

- The sprite should move up, down, left, and right if the corresponding arrow key is pressed.
- The sprite should _not_ go all the way off the screen in any direction.

# Do This Together

Before you tackle writing this program, you'll need to figure out how to check multiple conditions at once.

* **Brainstorm** with your neighbors ways you might check for more than one condition.
* **Share** back with the whole class so you can see other potential approaches.
* **Explore** the toolbox for blocks that might help (pay extra attention to the Math and Control drawers).
* **Program** your proposed solution.
* **Test** your program to make sure it's actually checking all of the conditions you intended.

markdown_instructions.CSD U3 Conditional Project_markdown_inst:
# Get Creative

At this point you have all of the tools necessary to make an interactive animation or simple game of your own design! This is your chance practice using all of the blocks you've seen so far, and to experiment with blocks you haven't used yet.

# Do This

Design an interactive animation of your own. Your program should -

- Use conditionals to get keyboard input
- Use conditionals to react to a sprite's properties
- Allow a user to move one or more sprites around the screen
- Change multiple sprite properties through conditionals

_You might notice some new blocks in the Sprites drawer, experiment with them and see if you can incorporate them into your conditionals._

# The Counter Pattern

This pattern is one of the most important ones in all of programming. 

![](https://images.code.org/83af2e40443ab294ba635f2a01a48ac7-image-1465506512065.06.56 PM.png)
    
It is used to increase the value of a variable by 1. You might call it the **counter pattern** since it can be used to make a variable that counts up. You'll use this pattern a lot, especially with the draw loop. Let's see what that looks like.

# Do This

This program creates a variable `counter` and then uses the **counter pattern** to make it count up. When you run the program what do you think you'll see on the screen?

* **Read the program** and make a prediction of what the output will be.
* **Run the program** to check your prediction.
* **Discuss with a neighbor**. Can you explain what you observed?
