markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_1_markdown_instr:
This cloud is blocking my view! 

Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud, and only get nectar if there's a flower.   
Be careful, it can change!
markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_2_markdown_instr:
More clouds! 

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar.  

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_4_markdown_instr:
Sometimes this cloud covers a flower, and sometimes it covers a honeycomb! 

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar only if it is a flower.  
Else, make honey (because it is a honeycomb).
markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_5_markdown_instr:
There will be either a flower or a honeycomb under each of those clouds!

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar if there is a flower.
Otherwise, make honey (because there is a honeycomb).
markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_6_markdown_instr:
I am not sure how much nectar this flower has, but I know it has either 1, 2, or 3 nectar. 

Combine the conditional blocks (`if` and/or `if/else`) to only get as much nectar as the flower has. 

Remember, the amount of nectar can change each time you run the puzzle!
markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_7_markdown_instr:
These flowers can have 3, 2, or 1 nectar. 

Complete the `check purple flower` function and use it to collect all of the nectar at the flowers.
markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_8_markdown_instr:
Write the function for `check flower make honey`. 

Your function should check if the purple flower has 3, 2, or 1 nectar and get all of the nectar. 
Then, move forward and make honey.
markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_9_markdown_instr:
**Assessment:** This cloud is either hiding a flower with one nectar or a honeycomb that needs one honey.  

Complete the `get nectar or make honey` function, then call it to collect the nectar or honey.
markdown_instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_TeacherIDo_markd:
There will be either a flower or a honeycomb under each of those clouds!

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar if there is a flower.
Otherwise, make honey (because there is a honeycomb).

markdown_instructions.grade3_Conditionals_11 BAD_markdown_inst: **Assessment:** Use a `while` loop to collect all of the nectar from these flowers.

You must first check if the nectar is equal to 1 using the `if nectar` block.

Can you figure out how to pick the pumpkin?  Make sure to collect all of the corn along the way!
markdown_instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_7_markdown_instructio: **Challenge:** Collect all of the corn and lettuce, then pick the pumpkin.
markdown_instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_8_markdown_instructio: Harvesting one type of crop at a time takes too long. Can you help me harvest both wheat and potatoes in one run? I wonder if you can stack another While There is... loop on top of another one?
markdown_instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_9_markdown_instructio: Can you help me one last time? I want to collect as many crops as I can before the weeds take over this field. How many do you think we can get?
markdown_instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_new1a_markdown_i: You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower.
markdown_instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_new2a_markdown_i:
In this puzzle, we know that every flower has exactly one nectar, but the flowers aren't spaced evenly.

Get all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible.
markdown_instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_new3b_markdown_i:
Conditionals can be helpful, even when you know exactly what is in each spot!

Collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_quantum1_markdow:
*"This cloud is blocking my view!"*

Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud. If there's a flower, get nectar.
markdown_instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_quantum2_markdow:
More clouds! 

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar.  

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
markdown_instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_quantum3_markdow:
*"Now I just want to make honey."*

Some of these clouds might have honeycombs under them.  Be sure to check if a honeycomb is hiding behind each cloud!
markdown_instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_quantum4_markdow:
Sometimes a cloud covers a flower, sometimes it covers a honeycomb! 

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar at flowers and make honey at honeycomb.
markdown_instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_quantum5_markdow:
**Challenge:** There will be either a flower or a honeycomb under each of those clouds!

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar if there is a flower.
Otherwise, make honey (because there is a honeycomb).
markdown_instructions.grade3_maze_Loop1_markdown_instruction: **Assessment:**  Get me to the sunflower using only 5 blocks!
markdown_instructions.grade3_maze_loops1_markdown_instruction:
*"Must...eat...sunflower!"*

Get the zombie to the sunflower.
markdown_instructions.grade3_maze_loops2_markdown_instruction: Get the zombie to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!
markdown_instructions.grade3_maze_loops2a_markdown_instruction:
*"Zombie hungry!"*

Get the zombie to the sunflower using the fewest number of blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.grade3_maze_loops3_markdown_instruction:
*"Must eat sunflower!"*

Get the zombie to the sunflower using only the blocks available.
markdown_instructions.grade3_maze_nestedLoops2_markdown_instru:
Suddenly, a magical block appears!  With the `repeat` block, you can loop code over and over.

Can you get to the pig by creating a loop that uses only one `move forward` block inside of a `repeat`?
markdown_instructions.grade3_maze_nestedLoops3_markdown_instru: Get me to the pig! You can only use one `move forward` block this time
markdown_instructions.grade3_maze_nestedLoops4_markdown_instru: In this puzzle, two `repeat` loops will help you get to the pig with the fewest number of blocks!
markdown_instructions.grade4_arist_functions_star0_markdown_in: Have you drawn something like this star before? Practice making it one more time by adding a `turn` and a `repeat` block.

markdown_instructions.grade4_playlab_freeplay_markdown_instruc:
It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
Need some ideas?
  • Tag - Have character 2 patrol and use your arrow keys to make character 1 chase until they collide.
  • Whack-a-Sprite - Have a character constantly pop up at a random location. Award points for clicking the sprite before it disappears.
  • Best Guess - Make both characters disappear, change location to a random spot, then reappear as a random character. Click on the first one and get a point...but if you click on the second one you LOSE a point!
markdown_instructions.grade4_playlab_test2_markdown_instructio:
Here's a function called `jump` that causes your main character to jump up 100 pixels. 

Run the program and use the jump function to collect all of the flags by moving the dog with the arrow keys.
markdown_instructions.grade4_review_artist2_markdown_instructi: This house needs a roof! Draw the triangle. Hint: all three sides are the same length.
markdown_instructions.grade4_review_artist3_markdown_instructi: The jump block moves the artist without drawing. Draw the dashed line using both the `jump forward` and `move forward` blocks. Each line is 50 pixels long.
markdown_instructions.grade4_review_bee1_markdown_instruction: Now use the `repeat` block to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.grade4_review_bee3_markdown_instruction:
Such a busy bee!

Help Bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey with the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project1_markdown_inst:
It is amazing how much you have learned! Let's put them together to make a game, step by step.
To start, let's set up your game's space and actor. We've put these blocks in your tool box. Choose a background and map, and pick an actor to be your game's hero.

![](https://images.code.org/745931ce34b3c47de19c36009e4a9c48-image-1471464938470.14.47 PM.png)
markdown_instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project2_markdown_inst:
Now let's get things moving! Use event handlers and actions to make your hero move.

We've added these blocks to your tool box to help you.

![](https://images.code.org/6216c0559cfae16005ffb53e6532473b-image-1471472994205.23.54 PM.png)
markdown_instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project3_markdown_inst:
Now that your game has a hero, it's time to start adding other actors and assigning them behaviors. 

Add two or more additional actors to your game and make them move. Do you want to have an actor patrol back and forth? Try using a these new blocks to bring these other components of your game to life!

![](https://images.code.org/4cfffd476c6129891eb8bde246a711a8-image-1472065288448.00.42 PM.png)

**NOTE:** Chasing and fleeing behavior commands are coming soon!
markdown_instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project4_markdown_inst:
Just getting the actors moving is a great step, but we need to program some interactions to make this really feel like a game. A simple way to do this is to add or remove points when actors collide with projectiles or each other. Find some interesting ways to change the score in your game.

*Don't expect to get this right on the first try. Keep testing your game as you code. You'll not only want a game that works, but one that is fun to play!*

We've added these blocks to your toolbox:

![](https://images.code.org/ad0df96aa91c89e3d903dce2fe19517f-image-1472070105051.20.55 PM.png)
markdown_instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project4a_markdown_ins:
Just getting the actors moving is a great step, but we need to program some interactions to make this really feel like a game. A simple way to do this is to add or remove points when actors collide with projectiles or each other. Find some interesting ways to change the score in your game.

*Don't expect to get this right on the first try. Keep testing your game as you code. You'll not only want a game that works, but one that is fun to play!*

![](https://images.code.org/876b13abf8a7984f94342dd9a5c8a8f0-image-1472069578010.42.30 PM.png)
markdown_instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project5_markdown_inst:
Great job! You have all the basic components of a working game. Now spend some time making sure the game works the way you want. Try including a way to win or lose your game.

*Don't forget: Keep testing your game as you code. You'll not only want a game that works, but one that is fun to play!*

Your toolbox has been re-organized to make it easier to find what you need. We've also added these blocks:

![](https://images.code.org/59b92b4c288bd5fc0c3be355c968f3d1-image-1472074578380.27.57 PM.png)
markdown_instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project6_markdown_inst: You've finished! Now you can play your game or share it with your friends and classmates!
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_binary1_markdown_instructi:
Binary is a way of representing information using only two options.  Here, we're going to use the options "off" (represented by the number 0) and "on" (represented by the number 1).   

We've provided you with a grid of "pixels" that you can walk through and make designs by turning on only certain squares.  

**Can you have the artist draw "01010101" in binary in the first row?**
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_binary10_markdown_instruct: **Free-Play Inspiration:** You've now learned everything you need to know to make a pattern like this! If this picture inspires you, try to make something similar. Otherwise, create something all your own.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_binary2_markdown_instructi:
Here's a function that takes a binary string of 1's and 0's and instructs the artist to follow them from left to right, top to bottom.  

The artist will fill-in the squares when it sees a 1 and ignore the square when it sees a 0. 

**Run this code to see how the artist uses binary to draw this pattern.**

markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops8_markdown_instru:
Remember back in a previous stage when we used a variable to control the number of sides in a shape? We are going to do the same thing with the `counter` variable now.  

This pattern starts with a triangle and adds one side at a time until it draws a decagon (10 sides). Each side should be 100 pixels long. 

How will you use the `counter` variable from the `for` loop to recreate this drawing?

markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_freeplay14_markd:
**Free Play**: Check it out! Now your algorithm is nested within one more loop. Experiment with changing the values of your two variables to draw cool patterns.

For even more effect, try playing with color!  Use random colors inside loops to see how it changes your design.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_freeplay15_markd: **Free-Play Inspiration:** You've now learned everything you need to know to make a pattern like this! If this picture inspires you, try to make something similar. Otherwise, create something all your own.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_hexagons1_markdo:
Let's try it again! 

Can you set the `length` variable to 60 to make this cool design with hexagons?
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_letterT11_markdo:
Heres some more complicated code using the same concepts from the last puzzle - what should you set the `sides` variable to in order to draw this picture made of squares?

Just for fun: Try using a few different numbers to see what happens to the pattern!
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_octagons13_markd:
When a shape has lots of sides, each side needs to be shorter if you want the whole pattern to fit on the screen. 

Let's recreate the algorithm for this amazing pattern, but instead of manually setting the `length` variable, let's use a math block with the `sides` variable inside to make sure that each shape fits correctly.  

The perimeter of each polygon is 300 pixels.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_pentagon8_markdo:
Use what you learned in the last puzzle to create this hexagon using the `sides` variable.

See how you could change just one value to draw a triangle,  square, pentagon, or octagon?
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_pentagon9_markdo: Now, recreate the algorithm from the last level and create a pentagon with sides of length 150.
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_pentagons1_markd:

See how you only have to set the value for `length` once, and the code uses the right value everywhere?
markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_rectangle6_markd: Now I want to make a rectangle that is twice as tall as it is wide. We've got a variable called `width` that needs to be set to 100. Can you use the math blocks to complete the code?

markdown_instructions.grade5_artist_variables_triangles3_markd: Drag a number block to the `set length` block and to the `repeat _ times` block to draw a set of 50 pixel triangles.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops10_markdown_instruct:
If your loop is counting down, the increment is **subtracted** from your counter variable each time through. 

What should your increment be to collect 15, then 12, then 9, 6, 3 nectar?
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops11_markdown_instruct:
**Challenge:** Take what you've learned about `for` loops and try to solve this problem. 

Remember: You may have to run through solutions multiple times before you figure out all of the steps.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops2_markdown_instructi:
Add the code necessary to make sure the bee collects all the nectar.

Look at how much code you need for this puzzle! (We'll learn a simpler way in the next puzzle.)
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops3_markdown_instructi:
Ah, the `for` loop makes this much easier!  

Try this puzzle using the `for` loop with `counter` variable and see how much shorter your code becomes.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops4_markdown_instructi: Help the bee collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops5_markdown_instructi: Now we need to `move forward` `counter` times, then `get nectar` `counter` times.  Can you use two `repeat` loops to solve this challenge?
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops6_markdown_instructi: You can also use a `for loop` to count down. Try gathering this nectar by counting down from 5 to 1 by 1.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops7_markdown_instructi:
The last number in your `for` loop is called the **"increment"**.  Each time the loop is run, the counter variable changes by the value of the increment.

Try collecting these flowers using an increment of 2.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops8_markdown_instructi:
You've got this!  

What should your increment be to collect 3, 6, 9, 12, 15 nectar?
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops9_markdown_instructi:
Now, let's combine the `counter` variable with a math block! 

How can you use the `counter` variable to navigate this garden with the fewest number of blocks possible?
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new1_markdown_inst: Check beneath the clouds to see if the flowers have any nectar.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new3_markdown_inst:
Time to put the function to the test! 

Let's see if it makes collecting these three rows of nectar any easier.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new4_markdown_inst:
*"How is your function holding up?"*   

We need to make some adjustments here. Click "edit" to add a `length` parameter to the function so that it will still work when the row is a different length.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new5_markdown_inst:
*"You're doing great so far!"*

Let's use this function to collect a lot of nectar.
markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new7_markdown_inst: **Challenge:** Something looks a little different. Can you modify your function to make honey as well?

markdown_instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new9a_markdown_ins: Use your new function to solve this spiral.
markdown_instructions.grade5_pixelation_markdown_instruction:
# Make your own image of any size

![](https://images.code.org/01c15fed4f1a2c6c3af531edc35e736e-image-1439596066108.png)
![](https://images.code.org/24efcaa184d1fc852f37c32911b3b87c-image-1439596070178.png)
![](https://images.code.org/c9a5d0fd5ba445b7f6b5744e08b50e49-image-1439596071878.png)
![](https://images.code.org/f14e1b8dd722b0ca5bc54fa96b34f2eb-image-1439596074236.png)
![](https://images.code.org/fe938c0c16453b9d461b4023098079df-image-1439596075744.png)
![](https://images.code.org/02c88a7da51289b2f2d1f64bd8c97b28-image-1439596077514.png)
![](https://images.code.org/309e3157dcfd91956181007f483f8e58-image-1439596079084.png)


**Directions:**

* Encode an image of anything you like using `binary`.
* The binary language will be represented with `0` and `1` only.
* You might want to do some planning and sketching with graph paper first. 
* Depict something, perhaps your name written out, your initials, an icon or logo of some sort.
* Get creative! The image doesn't have to be a perfect square, it can be long and skinny.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_freeplay_markdown_instruc:
It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
Need some ideas?
  • Tag - Have character 2 patrol and use your arrow keys to make character 1 chase until they collide.
  • Whack-a-Sprite - Have a character constantly pop up at a random location. Award points for clicking the sprite before it disappears.
  • Best Guess - Make both characters disappear, change location to a random spot, then reappear as a random character. Click on the first one and get a point...but if you click on the second one you LOSE a point!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables10_markdown_inst: Edit the the `patrol` function to add an `actor` parameter, so that we can call it for each of the actors on the screen. Remember, the actors correspond to numbers 1, 2, and 3.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables11_markdown_inst: Add another parameter called `speed` to the `patrol` function. Try using a `set speed` block with the new `speed` parameter to help Penguin get both flags before the other sprites even get one.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables12_markdown_inst:
Let's have some fun! Look at the code provided to see if you can figure out what each block does.  

When you're done, use the arrow keys to control Dog and collect all of the flags.

**NOTE:** You don't need to make any changes to the program
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables13_markdown_inst: Use the `when actor touches` block to send Dog back to the top-left ONLY if Dog touches any of the other actors.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables14_markdown_inst:
It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
Need some ideas?
  • Tag - Have character 2 patrol and use your arrow keys to make character 1 chase until they collide.
  • Whack-a-Sprite - Have a character constantly pop up at a random location. Award points for clicking the sprite before it disappears.
  • Best Guess - Make both characters disappear, change location to a random spot, then reappear as a random character. Click on the first one and get a point...but if you click on the second one you LOSE a point!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables1ask_markdown_in:
This time, when you press 'run', you will see a 'prompt' asking you for a number. This number will be stored in a variable used to set the dog's speed.


Pay attention to how this program is written!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables2_markdown_instr: The race in that last puzzle wasn't very fair! Change the `dog_speed` variable to make sure you can collect more flags than Cat. The first to collect 10 flags wins!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables3_markdown_instr:
Here's a new kind of game! 

You don't need to change anything on this level.

**Directions:** Use the left and right arrows to move, and the up arrow to jump. See if you can collect all of the flags.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables4_markdown_instr: Now we're using a variable called `height` to control how high the dog can jump. Update the `height` variable so that the dog can jump high enough to reach all the flags.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables6_markdown_instr:
In our game, how should we score points?

1. Add 1 to your `points` variable each time Dog hits Cat with a piece of pie.
2. Use the `when actor 2 touches anything` event to trigger an update to your score. You can increment your variable by setting `points = points + 1.`
3. Get your score up to 10 to pass the level.

**Note:** Use the right arrow to throw pie!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables6ask_markdown_in:
This time, you need 100 points to win!  Don't worry though, you can choose how many points you earn each time you score a hit!
Try adding the `ask` block and changing the number 1 out for the variable `value`.

**Note:** Use the right arrow to throw pie!
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables7_markdown_instr:
Nice, now let's make sure this game isn't too easy to play!

Any time Dog (actor 1) gets hit by a sandwich from Cat (actor 2), you should lose a point.

Start with 10 points so it's not too hard. Let your score drop down from 10 to 0 to pass the level.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables9_markdown_instr:
Here's a function called `patrol`. 

Edit `patrol` to move Cat up 400 pixels and then down 400 pixels.
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables_freeplay_markdo:
Free Play time! Here are all of the variables we've played with so far in this stage, as well as a few more in case you want them. 

Notice that there are now so many blocks in our toolbox that they need to be organized!  Here, we've put each piece into an appropriate category.  Take some time to explore everything that is available. When you're done browsing, make a game or story using repeats, variables, and events.  

*Hint: scroll down to see all the commands in the workspace.*
markdown_instructions.grade5_playlab_variables_jump1_markdown_: This puzzle uses a hidden function that makes the dog jump when the `up` arrow is pressed. The height of the jumps can be set at the start of the game using the `jumpPower` variable. Try to touch all of the flags!
markdown_instructions.grade5_prompt_test_markdown_instruction: Variables aren't always numbers. What if you wanted to store a word or text? Experiment with the new `ask` block.

markdown_instructions.harvey_snowflake_artist1_markdown_instru: *It's time to get your snowflake ready for 3d printing!* ![](https://images.code.org/ba50acd509bd25e07e7d4622a86ba158-image-1503785370113.08.08 PM.png)In order for your image to print correctly, follow these rules: * Make sure your image is all **one piece**! Separate pieces will print separately. * Make sure your image **fits** entirely on the canvas * Use just **black lines** on a white background. * Jump the artist off the top left corner (-10 over, -10 down) at the end of your program: -10-10 7 When you are finished, right-click to save the image, then send it to me on Google Classroom.

Separate pieces will print separately. * Make sure your image **fits** entirely on the canvas * Use just **black lines** on a white background. * Jump the artist off the top left corner (-10 over, -10 down) at the end of your program: -10-10 7 When you are finished, right-click to save the image, then send it to me on Google Classroom.

markdown_instructions.instructional-strategy-tuesday_markdown_:
# Day 2: Instructional Strategies

Name two Instructional Strategies (from the Curriculum Guide) you saw modeled in the 5 Model Lesson or TLOs youve seen in the past couple of days?

* When were they successful?
* What were characteristics of situations where there was room for improvement?

markdown_instructions.kikiTesta_markdown_instruction:
Our adventurer wants to collect coins.  But she can only use 4 blocks to get them.  

Can you help her grab as many as she can using just 4 blocks?
markdown_instructions.lesson-exploration-tuesday_markdown_inst:
# Day 2: Lesson Exploration

You have seen 2 Model Lessons (taught by facilitators) and today you will see 1 more Model Lesson and  2 Participant TLOs (taught by teachers). What patterns do you notice about what facilitators do during these sessions (consider the lessons themselves and the debriefs)?

* What are facilitators doing during lesson?
* What are facilitators doing during debrief?
* What are teachers doing throughout the session?
* What is the key takeaway from the session?
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_10_markdown_instruct:
Such a busy bee!

Help Bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey with the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_11_markdown_instruct:
The shape of this path is different from the others. 

Can you collect all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible?
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_3_markdown_instructi: Use a `repeat` loop to collect all of the nectar.
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_4_markdown_instructi: Now use the `repeat` block to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_5_markdown_instructi:
What a beautiful field of flowers!   

Help the bee visit each one.

Can you find a way to do it with fewer than 7 blocks?
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_6_markdown_instructi:
How many times can loops help you in this puzzle?  

Loops are your friend! Use a few of them to complete this puzzle with the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.level 'grade3_Loops_7_markdown_instructi:
Those flowers look tasty!

Collect nectar from each of the flowers using the fewest blocks possible.
markdown_instructions.loop pet test 2_markdown_instruction:
**CHALLENGE!** When Daisy gets a carrot, she gets excited. Can you make Daisy start doing a dance party? She should never stop, even after you take the carrot away.

You will have to use all these blocks:
![](https://images.code.org/83c295bd00536dffed3c93a40bba75ae-image-1523562330282.41.06 PM.png)
markdown_instructions.loop pet test 3_markdown_instruction:
**Make Predictions!** Write down your answers to these questions before clicking "Run". Then try the code and see what happens!

* What will Daisy the dog do after you drag the carrot to her?
* What will Daisy the dog do after you press the Up arrow key?
markdown_instructions.loop pet test 4_markdown_instruction:
**It's time to make your own virtual pet!** You can change whatever code you want to to make your own pet. Here are some ideas:

* Can you make your pet start something new when you click on it?
* Can you make your pet run away when you drag the vacuum to it?
* Can you add other animal friends to your pet's area?
markdown_instructions.love_spring_1_markdown_instruction:
Let's celebrate Spring!  

We have put some seeds in the ground to prepare for the season's flowers.  Can you cover them up so that the birds don't eat them?
markdown_instructions.love_spring_2_markdown_instruction:
Our flowers are in full bloom!  

Now we need the bee to grab nectar from each one so he can make plenty of honey back at his hive!
markdown_instructions.maker workshop final_markdown_instructio:
# Challenge: Explore!

Now that you've tested the waters a bit, go explore the full extent of this tool. On this level you'll see lots of new blocks and even some completely new areas of functionality (like a database backend!). Feel free to go back to previous levels for inspiration, or go off and building something completely your own.
markdown_instructions.mike3bit_markdown_instruction:
# 3-Bit Color
**Directions:**

* We start you with the 4x2 image Maddie was creating, but we've left out the last few pixels. 
* Finish off the image by figuring out which colors are missing and encoding them.
markdown_instructions.mike3bitbird_markdown_instruction:

markdown_instructions.mike3bitfreeplay_markdown_instruction:

You have one last chance to experiment and get creative with the pixelation widget. Make something awesome and share it with your classmates!

* *Hint:* You can copy and paste the value of a pixel to use it repeatedly.
markdown_instructions.mike3bitmario_markdown_instruction:
# 3-Bit Color
 
**Challenge:** 

A careless binary coder typed in ONE extra 0 or 1 somewhere within this image's data. The extra bit that is causing Mario to glitch out! 

Delete the extra bit to restore Mario back to normal!

markdown_instructions.name 'CSD U3 Keypress Boolean Predict'_m:
# Make a Prediction: keyDown()
The `keyDown()` block is the first of a new set of blocks that will let us get input from the user. This is the first step on our road to actually making games! See if you can figure out how the `keyDown()` block works.

What do you think will happen when you run the program and press the "up" arrow? Write your prediction below and then run the program to see if your prediction was accurate.
markdown_instructions.novice-monday-1_markdown_instruction:
# Day 1 Question 1

Think back on your experience today.

* Use a few words or sentences to describe how you felt as a participant during those sessions today (e.g., confused, engaged, anxious, etc.)
* What factors contributed to you feeling that way? 
* Did you feel supported as a participant today? Why?
* What does your experience today make you think about your role as a facilitator?

What else can you do in this fun scene?
Need some ideas?

  • Pinball - Make one sprite play a noise when the other runs into it.
  • Arrows - Write a program so when each arrow key is pressed, the sprite moves in that direction!

markdown_instructions.recruiting-thursday_markdown_instruction:
# Day 4: Recruiting

In the Recruiting Students session this morning you talked about recruiting students and meeting students needs in the region where you work. (If you were not with your region think about what you experienced in this sessions that might apply to your region.)

* What were common recruiting pain points teachers in your region shared?
* What were common student support needs teachers in your region shared?
* What things did you see today that you want to check in on throughout the year?

markdown_instructions.subgoals_u3_top_down_FR_markdown_instruc:
# Design a program

Describe, using a top-down approach, how you would create a program to draw a white snowflake on a blue background that uses random numbers, so the snowflake will be unique every time you run the code. 

You dont need to write the exact code or blocks that you would use, but you should describe what functions you would need to create, where you would or would not use loops, and where you would or would not use random numbers.
markdown_instructions.subgoals_u3_top_down_FR_2018_markdown_in:
# Design a program

Describe, using a top-down approach, how you would create a program to draw a white snowflake on a blue background that uses random numbers, so the snowflake will be unique every time you run the code. 

You dont need to write the exact code or blocks that you would use, but you should describe what functions you would need to create, where you would or would not use loops, and where you would or would not use random numbers.

markdown_instructions.test peer review_markdown_instruction: At this point you've seen 7 of the 14 lessons from unit 1. Thinking about those lessons, and looking across the other lessons in unit 1 work with your partner to develop a set of recommendations for using group work and peer learning in Unit 1. Your recommendations should include: - Which lessons or activities provide opportunities for group work and peer learning? - What recommendations do you have for using group work and peer learning in Unit 1 lessons? Use the space below to record any recommendations or commentary you have for others. Once you submit, another participant will review chance to send you feedback!

markdown_instructions.u3-old-drawing-view_markdown_instruction:
# Your Own Drawing

It is your turn to create your own drawing. You should have drawn out your plan on paper first.

# Do This
As a reminder make sure you hit the objectives:

* Creates an identifiable and named object or design (i.e. no random splatters of shapes)
* Uses at least 10 shapes or text items (rect, ellipse, regularPolygon, text)
* Uses at least 4 different color fills
* Uses at least 2 different color outlines
* Contains at least 3 different logical blocks of code with comments
